job_title: Director in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great School, that offers good programs to help people get a good career.
cons: Office is older, stuff everywhere... could use a good remodel!

pros: Free parking easily accessible to highway
cons: Pay was low and inconsistent

pros: Honestly, nothing is considered as a Pros, it's only you feel good when you give people a chance to learn from you. Its also you get so thankful when when you quit working there and students only reach out to show appreciation and give their honest opinion that they only learn this or that from you.
cons: The college is like groups, especially the management they have their favorites, and you need to be cheap spy/snitch to be their favorite, its like you are living a primary or secondary school age. If you have you own standards, values, and morals you will not be a good fit to work there. People who are in management are not really qualified. No matter what you do and being exceptional you will not be appreciated or get a (Thank you) from the management team. Add to that employee in management position always try to passively disrespect the employees, and what make it worse that the higher management try to act that they are unaware of these issues and act blind. If you are wondering how I would say all that and stayed to work there, the answer is because I know how to handle all that and how to put a limit, and I was waiting for my right position to leave.

pros: Family oriented Excellent culture Small classes
cons: Pay is okay Location Turn over

pros: There are some highly intelligent and caring faculty, but many aren't treated well, unless they comply with the nursing management! Some that will go out of their way to attempt to keep positivity and to help students that are struggling with the affects of upper management.
cons: Terrible place. The hostility, intimidation of students by nursing assistant dean, zero compliance to their own policy, lack of documentation, etc, would be just a few reasons not to waste your time. The nursing management faculty have zero care for student success, only for money. If you manage to expose nursing management of their ill doings of students they have no problem fabricating lies to cover themselves. Financial aid should be ashamed with their adding charges, doubling tuition fees, not documenting anything, nobody knows what they're doing, etc. Communication is a terrible issue and the scheduling is ridiculous. Many added schedule changes or plain not having one until the last minute, and policy is about as useless as the link it's attached to, or paper written on

review_title: Not about the students or the instructors. Its all about the $.
pros: Rate of pay Adult students
cons: No advancements, administration plays favorites, instructors are not listened to and are often blamed for things beyond their control, administration is rude and talk down to employees. This campus is toxic.

pros: Flexibility is a pro when you are not being micromanaged.
cons: You are told you're an admissions advisor but really you're a glorified sales representative. no room for growth, no raise, upper management only cares about increasing sales and not actually helping students transform their lives and start a career.

review_title: Does not care about faculty or students at all
pros: Faculty really cares about students success and wellbeing.
cons: So called “Leadership “ can care less about feedback from the faculty who by the way are at the forefront of dealing with the students. They sit in meetings and gossip about staff. The gossip is spread by the registrar to the staff lowering staff moral and causing a total disconnect in the team dynamics. The DOE

pros: Coworkers are great, helping the students is fullfilling.
cons: Management is not good, very pushy and pressuring us to enroll everyone that steps in the door

pros: I was able to teach and help students learn.
cons: Staff is very catty and toxic.

pros:
'Student success' is the primary focus in all strategies and operations
Committed to compliance 
Turning out excellent graduates - making a difference in the community
cons: The work is challenging and not for anyone looking for a laid back, casual work environment

pros: Hopeful students in need of education
cons: The company is unethical and highly lacking in integrity especially financial aid and the campus president

pros: Work from home, contract per hour not semester

job_title: Director of Admissions in Port Saint Lucie, FL
pros: Great place to work with A LOT of great people to work with! Very student focused and the instructors do their very best to ensure student success.
cons: There are no cons at this time.

pros: Faculty and Staff really work hard to help students. Good internal communication.
cons: Can get frustrating when policies change. Some students just go here to get $ and don;t take thir education seriously. Pay is mid level.

review_title: Great people (faculty and staff) to work with
job_title: Campus President in Port St Lucie, FL
pros:
No compliance issues
Better work/life balance than other schools
Loving the culture
cons: Could be more structured and supportive with some campus activities.

job_title: Financial Aid Officer II in Phoenix, AZ
pros: great students and instructors, laid back environment
cons: broke company, my entire time (4 years) no 401k match, no pay raise but i enjoyed my job so much it wasnt enough reason to leave. Unfortunately school ended up closing Phoenix location

pros:

Staff
Engaging

job_title: Hybrid Coordinator in Orange Park, FL
pros: Leadership and compliance was at a high level and each person I worked with was highly skilled.
cons: I loved working here but it was understood that raises were out of the question

review_title: Poor work environment, little interest in education
pros: Not many! Hours are great if you can afford to survive with the pay. Good schedule for parents and family life outside of work.
cons: No support from management unless they personally like you. No interest from management to get to know employees. No personal, in class observations. They sign off on them, but do not actually perform them. President and Dean never do classroom observations but heavily criticized and judge class management skills. No constructive criticism. No official annual review. Limited to 22 hours a week, unless you tutor. In that case you may not exceed 26 hours. Your time will be adjusted and you will be threatened with a write up. There is no actual planning time, and based on the limited hours, you will be working unpaid VERY often if you are fully invested in your job. The equipment is poor, outdated, broken, supplies are limited and supply budgets are tight. No IT person on campus, so you are on your own to provide computer access to host class online. You are expected to resolve the issues yourself, aka: being in your own personal laptop to perform your job. Leadership is very one sided and partial to certain people. There is a lot of backbiting amongst the teams. Smile to your face, and then talk poorly about you in front of students. Inside/personal relationships between upper management and department heads. Instructors smoking in parking lot with students. Cash gifts given to students. Personal businesses being advertised to students for profit.

pros: Run as fast as you can
cons: Negative working environment; toxic all day

review_title: Stressful, no  concern for employee welfare
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Cuyahoga Falls, OH
pros: I earned a paycheck there.
cons: Campus President doesn’t care about you as a person. Expected to work 24/7 with no work/life balance. No teamwork, everyone is in CYA mode or playing favorites within little cliques. Unrealistic expectations of job performance.

job_title: Billing and Coding Instructor in Homewood, AL
pros: The building of learning is very nice and clean
cons: No room to advance in other roles and toxic environment

job_title: Allied Health Instructor in Columbus, OH
pros: Flexibility in schedule, vacation time, pay
cons: Management, class loads, communication, lab supplies, disorganized

pros: Virtual with covid, pay is reasonable
cons: Leadership is toxic high employee turnover

pros: Good team to working with.
cons: Lot of unpaid prep time

pros: Good team and supportive environment
cons: Corporate interferes with effective curriculum and delivery

pros: Very flexible work schedule. Students are eager to learn
cons: None, I love this job and the administration

pros: Very well organized and lots of interaction with students.
cons: The campus needed to be refreshed.

pros: Co workers are cool to work with
cons: Too much work for one employee. Have to work day and night to keep up with the emails.

job_title: Admissions Representative in Cuyahoga Falls, OH
pros: Good amount of pto given
cons: Have to start so many, can’t use pto

pros: Really great place to work. Wonderful education.
cons: Atlanta Traffic is really bad.

review_title: Not a good company to work for
pros: There are many faculty and staff members that really care about the success of the students, while they are students and once they become graduates.
cons: Fortis College preys on the poor by advertising in markets that they are sure will attract just the type of "customer" they are looking for.  Education Affiliates, the company that owns Fortis College, is all about making money, no matter what they have to do to get it.  A student will pay more for their tuition and fees than what they will make in a year, once they have completed the program and start working.  Most of the students are at or below the poverty level but still basically forced to pay out of pocket.  When I say that, what I mean is that they are unaware that they don't legally have to pay out of pocket when they have a zero EFC.  In other words, they qualify for the maximum amount in federal aid. The instructors are undervalued and under-appreciated.  The staff is  forced to do multiple jobs that are sometimes outside of their job description because the company is too money hungry to hire the help needed.  Overall, the company does not care about the students, faculty, or staff.  They are for profit and all they want is money and will attempt to get it by any means necessary.  Education Affiliates is all about Education Affiliates and that's their bottom line.

pros: Working with SOME great people and helping students has been nice. Anything to assist students in their successful completion of their degree is very rewarding. There is a lot of work and that helps the days go by faster. Problem solving is very interesting and conducive to the position.
cons: Have worked in a hostile environment, being told inappropriate HR information, such as what other employees make and management bad-mouthing other upper level constituents. Upper management does not value departments that interface directly with students. No raises for lower level employees for 6 years and most likely that will not change because the company has serious budgeting issues. However upper management have been given raises. There is no room for growth, and there are no opinions allowed from employees that are not in management. There is no trust in the company and they do not believe in treating employees with respect or any type of value. The company treats student's like numbers and employees like disposable objects. The company hires incompetent individuals to try to run departments and the morale has increasingly become negative. I gave 1 star even though for each one, there are no stars that are deserving or worthy from this company.

job_title: Business Office Manager in Montgomery, AL
pros: easy work, allowed me to use my skills
cons: low pay, poor management, bad guidance

review_title: Toxic environment gets in the way of helping students
job_title: LRC Manager in Port Saint Lucie, FL
pros: Many of the students are actually going to be helped out of the cycle of poverty and have their lives changed. The other librarians in the Educational Affiliates system are very supportive. Many people working there are trying to do their best in the midst of a very incompetent organization and negative climate.
cons: I've never worked at a place so poorly run or with such a toxic environment. I worked there 3 years, and had four campus presidents; the current one is laughably incompetent, there's not a single person working there who has any respect for him. I once saw him walk right by a student who was being loaded into an ambulance without a glance, to continue on to ask an administrative assistant if she had some form; we all just looked at him like he was crazy. He seems to think that chewing people out is leadership. The climate is such that it's many people's goal to look for opportunities to stab each other in the back constantly. The best people leave pretty quickly. I've been lied to, stolen from, ignored, and bullied. Attempts to build bridges or communicate about why things are done, or what students should be told are ignored or ridiculed. Also, Fortis doesn't pay its bills, so occasionally, there's no paper for the students' printing or you can't order anything. Then you're the one who will be screamed at by students and faculty.

review_title: Speaking out both sides of their mouths
pros: Had fun with students- It was great changing people's lives and watching them graduate and get great jobs.
cons: From an admissions representative perspective, don't act like the industry is not numbers driven.  It is - and people get fired if they don't hit numbers.  Just because you tell people that we are now customer service reps but don't address how to hit the numbers and then act like you were never about numbers is ludacris. Don't hire a campus director that looks and smells like a used car salesman to come in to make it better that hates the admissions reps and then wonder why the Nashville campus has the lowest population it has ever had.

pros: Great opportunity and second part time job.  Making a difference in student's lives is an amazing feeling.  There are opportunities to advancement and promotion.  Good benefits and and pay for full time salaried employees. Amazing senior management.  Very flexible hours and a family oriented workplace.  Many opportunities to work from home.
cons: Teaching sometimes get laborious because instructors are given the task of contacting every student by phone in the first week of class.  From then on out instructors are required to contact failing students and submit weekly reports.  Not a bad policy, but the task can be a big one.  Students are sometimes not very academic and it is challenging to engage some of them.

pros: Nice campus - relatively easy sell, no focus on conversions or admissions metrics, nice pay scale, good benefits, some friendly coworkers.
cons: No training, no support from management, no advancement, no raises. Teachers were always unhappy and complaining so they weren't friendly to students.

pros: Rewarding when students were there to really learn. Very gratifying seeing your students succeed, knowing you've helped them accomplish their goals.
cons:
Not having up to date equipment sometimes. Not alot of support from upper management regarding students who should not pass a class, however, sometimes they will allow them to move on to next phase anyhow. Does not look good for the profession and does not sit well with me.
Also, your spend a lot of time off the clock preparing lectures, grading tests and homework. This is not anything new for teaching, but still unfair.

review_title: Being able to help people make a change and better their futures is something I get to look forward to here at Fortis.
job_title: Career Services Advisor in Baton Rouge, LA
pros:
Feels almost like a second home.
Great people to work with, everyone is very pleasant, and will to be apart of a team.
Great Benefits and pay.
cons:
Sometimes the management will play more into politics when it comes to promotions and recognition of employees, but then again show me a place that doesnt.
I can say that I have seen a change in this for the better.

review_title: Feels like a small college, must be doing something right
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Cuyahoga Falls, OH
pros: local flavor & atmosphere, students are keenly aware they are noticed & recognized for their accomplishments. Long serving management & many staff are 10+ year veterans.  Small technical & trade school environment, with a much better than anticipated nursing program.
cons: Slow moving in decision making. Expenditures & budget are very tight. Often bills are backed up due to processing problems corporately. Lack a stronger push for higher accreditation, so coursework often will not travel with students if they don't finish.

pros: The majority of employees really care about the student experience.
cons: Campus leadership is not engaged in what is going on in the work place. Sometimes you will be asked to do things that are outside your ethical boundaries. Too many people take a "that's not my job approach" to working there. Poor communication and lack of oversight by senior leadership. They really are not aware of what is really happening at the campus level. No pay increases the past three years. No career development or advancement opportunities.

review_title: Love the Job, Hate the Company
job_title: Online Advisor in Greenwood Village, CO
pros: The job itself is rewarding and keeps you on your toes while also feels comfortable. You are able to support students in bettering their lives and following their dreams. Your day consists of putting out fires and wearing many hats which is great for the person who enjoys multitasking and feeling like each day is different. There's also a lot of repetitive tasks which gives you a level of comfort once you have all the steps down. It's a great balance of knowing the job like the back of your hand but also finding new solutions to different problems. Also 17 days of PTO per year is lovely!
cons: The company itself, unfortunately. There are no raises, no 401K match, corporate/upper level don't even know who the Online Advisors are. They are more concerned with admissions and enrolling as many as they can, although they never take the time to set those students up for success. While they appear concerned with retention and graduation rates, they don't appreciate the Online Advisors who are literally  here to keep students in their classes and to support them in passing those classes. You'd think that upper level management would be appreciative of the OA's but they are not. We have been called "entry level" to our faces as an explanation for why we don't feel more valued. Being that the position requires a BA degree minimum and specific experience, I would not consider the OA position as entry level. It is not a job you can do right out of college like admissions, for example. Also, our position is not student facing and is technically remote but we are forced to come into an empty, dark and dingy office everyday. I would have loved to be able to do this job remotely from the comfort of my home - it would go a long way in my happiness. Even being able to monitor our emails, texts, phone calls, and CampusVue activity, we are not trusted to actually be remote employees.

pros: Good Pay, but not Great due to no raised in 5yrs.
cons:
No raises in 5yrs
No room for grown
You will never meet anyone from corporate and this company never has any type of team building activities. 
No 401K Match

job_title: Medical Assistant Instructor in Towson, MD
pros: If you want to teach, the ability to impact lives in a positive way for their future. This is the job. My students let me there for longer than I should have stayed.
cons: No raises the whole time I was there. No bonuses. No teamwork. The teachers now aren't properly certified. The program doesn't put quality learning into the students. I couldn't do it anymore.

pros:
Lots of opportunities for learning how to deal with difficult situations. I mean that in the best way, some jobs don't give you the opportunity to know how to fix issues and this one really does. 
They promote instructor educational growth with internal, mandatory classes. Once a year and when you start, you will be required to do these online classes.
cons:
The school "overlooks" situations with the students on many levels to make them pass or move on in the program. 
They also overlook their own rules within their college catalog that the instructors are suppose to enforce. Then when the student gets angry because they aren't doing what they should be doing and go to higher administration, they allow them to continue even though the student has failed, not been in class the proper time or they have been a threat to other employees/students. Very frustrating as someone who is supposed to be an authoritative figure and we have no backup on the clearly written rules.
There is plenty of work, and never enough time to do it all on campus. The amount of work can be overwhelming and take over your life.
The paperwork that goes with every little thing you have to do is a whole other job in itself. If you talk to a student about anything and everything you need to fill out a form for each student.

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Staff and faculty are truly concerned about the students. Everyone wants them to succeed. Management is very encouraging and you are given quite a bit of freedom in the classroom. If you want more hours...you just need to ask.
cons: Pay is slightly lower compared to other schools in the area. Adjunct instructors are paid for prep time, but it doesn't come close to the actual time spent preparing for class.

job_title: Learning Resource Center Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: It was a great job for the time, hours were flexible, co-workers were great, and most of the leadership were thought individuals.
cons: I left because I just got bored, after 7 years, no one had suggested that I retrain for some other position in the company.  Also fiscally the school was struggling which created a strained work environment.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Orange Park, FL
pros: It was great.  I worked under the old management when it was North Florida Institute.  Not sure about how to rate Fortis, but from what I have heard, it was a good time to get out!
cons: For profit education is mostly all the same.  It's all about making money and the management usually is horrible.  I got out before it got bad, but went to another school.  Like jumping from the frying pan into the fire.

review_title: Greedy, unhappy, disorganized work culture but good pay.
job_title: Admissions Representative in Cuyahoga Falls, OH
pros: They don't try very hard to pretend that the job doesn't suck.
cons: The job is monotonous, results are disappointing when dealing with students that can't commit to a lifestyle change, and there is little reward for hard work or meeting goals.

review_title: Great school for individuals looking to move from poverty to middle class with a average of 16 months of training
pros: Leadership, and staff, classrooms, and resources and benefits
cons:
We need more evening classes to accommodate work/school balance for  single parents.
Have more companies like Opportunity Inc to give grants to those who really need the help.  The individuals who are living in poverty should have more outlets rather than one source so that they can balance work and school.

job_title: Allied Health Instructor in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: Opportunity to work with non traditional students and provide them with training to give them attractive job skills for today's healthcare market
cons: No opportunity for advancement and the emphasis is on how much money can be made with bringing students in.  After they are enrolled little to no attention is given to the type of education provided.  Poor resources and little to no training for instructors.

job_title: Medical Assistant Instructor in Richmond, VA
pros: It feels good to give back to up and coming Medical Assistants and the knowledge that they will be successful because of it.
cons: Not being able to work full-time is a big con for me personally, the need for more hours is great unfortunately, causing me to look elsewhere.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: Co-workers were very helpful and friendly. There was never a shortage of supplies to fulfill the work tasks. Management staff delegated tasks in a respectful manner.
cons: Workload was high and compensation was low. The way tasks were assigned made the workload seem more hectic than it should've been.

job_title: IT Specialist in Orange Park, FL
pros:
Friendly Faculty and a  great opportunity to prove and or show my abilities. 
Average Pay. 
I enjoyed interacting with the students and offering my support and always with a smiling face.
cons:
Poor or lack of Management. Absolutely no communication what so ever.
I held 3 positions , IT Specialist , Audio Visual Technician , Building Maintenance.
Unless your a Full Time Employee you are very dispensable. A helper of my choice would have been very useful.

pros: Good teamwork, employees care about the students they serve, and admissions department pay is above-average for the industry.
cons: Too much pressure for admissions representatives to continue to perform in a market with increasing competition and declining enrollments, while management continues to use outdated marketing and methods. Everything can't be the fault of employees who have achieved such excellent results in the past.

pros: Great staff and it was enjoyable coming to work most days. Students were good also and easy to work with, made it fun
cons: Turnover was high and management didnt seem to want to keep good instructors. Seem to find a way to get rid of good people for no reason

pros: Fortis College is super laid back. It's family friendly. Anytime I've had a family emergency or needed time off, it's been granted without any hassle. Benefits are also phenomenal.
cons: So far, I haven't really encountered any cons. Naturally, is like to make more money and the company right now is not implementing yearly raises but other than that, I'm content.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Winter Park, FL
pros: Paycheck and talking with students
cons: Upper Management, President of the company, Nationals no idea we had an online division... 6 years, 6 presidents... Corporate was Clueless on how to run an online school. They thought of applying  ground rules to an online school would work..Well it didn't work is now Fortis Online is closed because of your genius way to micromanage and not train employees. Well done. People are without jobs and students are stuck with an useless education.

pros: Great opportunity to make money while in school. Nothing too busy to keep you from getting homework done. Plenty of ti.e to study for certifications! Boss is awesome!
cons: Lack of communication between departments allows important issues to fall between the cracks. A detriment to the other hard working staff tryi g to help the student. Some staff see students as bothersome instead of the reason they have a job to begin with!

pros: Great local management team that cares about the students' success, not just profitability.  The students are self-motivated, attentive and polite, for the most part.
cons: Lack of full-time opportunities, poorly equipped classroom labs; no benefits, no Benefits, NO BENEFITS!  Corporate management is almost totally unaware of our local campus and what makes us so successful.

review_title: Horrible Company with No Morals or Values!
pros: The ONLY good thing about Fortis are the students. They change your life and make coming to work the tiniest bit bearable. The students become your friends and you genuinely want to see them succeed. It's awful knowing that you played a part in one of the worst experiences of their life.
cons:
Where do I begin. The company/management/leadership doesn't give the slightest care about you. It's all about the bottom line. The only incentive used to keep employees motivated were fear tactics that always led with "there are thousands of other people out there who could do and want your job" or even "this is the most money you have ever made, I saw your resume." 
During the three years I was there I was denied my vacation time 70% of the time and ended up eating the rest of it. I was denied coming in early or leaving late for doctors appointments or family emergencies. During bad weather management would leave and not let staff or students leave. If you did leave so that you were able to get home safely, you were written up. 
They are a for profit school that legally isn't allowed to reprimand employees on numbers.. that doesn't stop them in the slightest! If you have an experience with admissions and it feels like they are being pushy, they are. Also keep in mind their job was most likely threatened within minutes of meeting you. 
Also, you do not get the chance to advance within the company. ESPECIALLY if you are good at the position you are in. Even worse, I was there for three years and never received a raise and had a day of pay taken due to the company struggling. They want to keep you stagnant. So if you are looking to start a career. Keep on moving. Admissions reps for a for profit college are comparable to a used car salesman.

review_title: Good learning opportunity, but highly unorganized
pros: Knowledgeable management team, excellent coworkers
cons: Late work hours. Mandatory work days (even on holidays or weekends) based on performance with late notice of mandatory days given. Negative undertone threats.

pros: Extremely friendly and helpful staff and upper management. New management has set stricter rules for students making it a much safer and easier environment to teach at. I have had many opportunities for advancement in only a year.
cons: The programs used to be very poorly run but now that new management has taken over, things are turning around. Pay is not as high as other comparable schools in the area.

job_title: Allied Health Instructor in Baltimore, MD
pros: I came here after working at a horrible school down the street. Here the management appreciates you and treats you with respect. The faculty are a part of the campus team.  I actually like coming to work again and my coworkers are like family.
cons: I have none at this time

review_title: Bad Management from the TOP down
job_title: Online Admissions in Winter Park, FL
pros: I receive a paycheck. That's it. There's 401K but company does not match. There's average health insurance.
cons: No raises. No employee motivation. Upper management clueless how to run an Online program. Spreadsheet and micro management type of environment. No recognition. Upper management doesn't know your name or position. No raises. I would not recommend a friend to work here. Top managers clueless how to run a business or motivate employees. Same routine everyday. Get enrollments or else.

pros: I honestly can't think of one thing.
cons: Administration is unsupportive. When asked for help, they fluff your feathers with empty words and send you on your way. They offer no real help or solutions. This student population is difficult to deal with. I was down right bullied by my students and administration did not protect me or intercede on my behalf.

pros: Decent training program for the admissions representatives.
cons: Low pay, micro-managed and the company lowers its standards to make quota's.

pros: Opportunity to impact students lives.
cons: Lack of business management training for senior management. to develop skills to actually run an organization.  Total disconnect between management and students; evident in number of students who enroll and dropout with massive debt. High turnover in instructors due to lack of training and communication combined with excessive responsibilities. Too many selective blinders.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Vey kind people. I felt like the work I did was appreciated and needed. There was also room for me to develop my own way of doing things and be more efficient.
cons: Not the greatest pay but not bad either. At times it seemed like the quality of works there was selected from a lower less accomplished group of individuals.

pros: You really get to be a part of something special in helping people achieve in most cases what they believed to be impossible.
cons: Micro management at highest level. You have to wonder what's wrong when 99% of the executive staff resigns

pros: Small class sizes.  One on one attention from instructors.  Very clean environment. Large parking lot. Students are very polite.
cons: The Parta bus does not run very late at night. The Instructor tries to find students to help with car pooling.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Port St Lucie, FL
pros:
The paychecks are generally on time.
Some good managers
cons:
Awful employer in the for-profit college industry. Expect to be overworked and underappreciated by management that usually has no clue as to what is going on outside their offices. When working there I always felt badly for our students who were being overcharged for a substandard education.
Do not ever expect a raise, your starting rate will always be your salary.

pros: Team work is promoted consistently.  The individuals put aside their personal accomplishments to ensure that the recruiting goals are met.
cons: Down-sizing, the 401 K was taken away at one point and the staff was not made aware until 5pm on a Friday the day of via email.

pros: Co-workers are amazing.. we were all in it together
cons: Where to start? Long hours! No policies in place. Campus management horrible! All about making money...Students lied to just to get them into door. Was more like a used car lot...Most of the faculty were more qualified than management..no money put into surroundings or supplies.

job_title: Director of Career Services in Ravenna, OH
pros: I am a newer employee to Fortis college and compared to the schools i previously worked at , this schools really focuses on student satisfaction.
cons: The only downside to being farout in Ravenna is limited bus options at night.

review_title: They pay high salaries to the directors and underpay faculty members and staff.
pros: They have a good benefits.
cons: Admission standards; you can't meet their quotes. You are valued through numbers; how many students are enrolled. That’s only what matters. Quantity instead of quality.

pros: Changing students lives is extremely rewarding and staff relationships can be unforgettable.
cons: Large staff turnover and unprofessional staff behaviors.

pros: Working here looks good until you arrive and are told the whole truth
cons: An internet search will reveal tuition that is up to ten times greater than nearby schools, pages and pages and pages of complaints from unhappy students with massive student loan debt and no prospect for employment, investigations and settlements by law enforcement agencies, fines and sanctions from regulators, probationary action by accrediting bodies, rip-off reports to the Better Business Bureau.

job_title: Allied Health Instructor in Dallas, TX
pros:
A very family oriented environment for the staff.
Everyone truly appreciate the next individuals job and task.
cons: I do not have anything negative to say at this time.

pros: Pay is decent (40k) benefits affordable for a single person, expensive for families.
